lines.text: Running's always been a big thing in our family, especially running away from the police.
And always remember, they've got the whip hand.

Do you know what I'd do if I had the whip hand? I'd get all the coppers, governers, posh whores, army officers and members of parliament and I'd stick them up against this wall and let them have it 'cause that's what they'd like to do to blokes like us.
You'll learn.
We'll see.
Now when you broke into this, um, what was it...
Bakery
Bakery, yup... what were you thinking about at the time?
I wasn't thinking about anything, I was too busy breaking in.
Just describe the action to me in your own words, put me in the picture.
Got over the wall of this baker's yard, broke into his office.
Hmm, I think you can do a bit better than this, Smith, um, surely your nerves were on edge weren't they, you felt afraid?
If I felt afraid I wouldn't have broken in, would I?
What's your name?
Smith.
Say "sir" when you answer the Governor.

[insolently]
Sir Smith.
That won't get you far here, lad.
Look, I'm nobody's favorite.
[first lines]

Running was always a big thing in our family, specially running away from the police. It's hard to understand. All I know is that you've got to run, running without knowing why, through fields and woods. And the winning post's no end, even though the barmy crowds might be cheering themselves daft. That's what the loneliness of a long distance runner feels like.
Come on doll, don't play hard to get.
I used to be a runner myself, quite a useful one too but a bit of a plodder.
There's other places besides London you know.
Well I don't think so.
They certainly drive themselves hard on the playing fields.
They're high-spirited Mr Brown.
If they weren't, they wouldn't be here.
You don't get anywhere without effort, do you lad?
How do we tackle the basic aggression which these lads obviously feel?
By channelling it in the right direction.
I was just wondering whether life wasn't a little more complicated than a football match.
You'll end up in prison one of these days.
If he aint careful.
It'd get me out of this dump.
It ain't the only way to get out of it.
It was that new lad Smith who scored that goal, wasn't it?
Right sir.
He can run.
He's not bad sir.
He might be useful to us, we better keep an eye on him.
Where d'you learn to drive like this?
Me cousin had a milk round.
That's five bob up the spout.
Share and share alike. All for one and one for all, united we stand, divided we fall.
You're a bloody poet, aren't you.

The best thing to do is be cunning and stay where you are. I'm going to let them think they've got me house trained, but they never will, the bastards. To get me beat, they'll have to stick a rope around my neck.
It's not that I don't like work. It's just that I don't like the idea of slaving me guts out so the bosses can get all the profits. Seems all wrong to me.
So, uh, how do you come to be here?

[puzzled]
I got sent, didn't I?

[chuckles]
Yes, I know you got sent, but why?
I got caught. Didn't run fast enough!
Well, you're a new boy in here, aren't you, Smith?
Yeah.
Yeah. So am I. Two new boys in here, in a matter of speaking. Perhaps we can help one another.
